banner.title: Step Into Our 3D Universe

banner.clickToStart: Click on the screen to start

welcome.heading: Guided Onboarding
welcome.subtitle: Explore the Kepler and Exo models interactively.

kepler.title: 🌍 Exoplanet: Kepler-186f
kepler.paragraph1: Kepler-186f orbits a red dwarf in the constellation Cygnus and is notable for being the first Earth-sized planet discovered in the habitable zone of its star — the region where liquid water could exist on the surface.
kepler.paragraph2: Classified as a Super Earth, Kepler-186f is larger and more massive than Earth but smaller than Neptune, likely with a rocky surface. Because its star is cooler and dimmer, the planet receives less stellar energy; if an atmosphere is present it may trap heat and moderate surface temperatures.
kepler.paragraph3: The discovery of Kepler-186f marked an important milestone in the search for potentially habitable worlds and helps inform how we model exoplanet climates and detection strategies.

userGuide.title: 🌌 3D Universe – User Guide
userGuide.welcome: Welcome to the 3D Universe Explorer, an interactive environment where you can explore distant exoplanets like Kepler-186f.

controls.leftMouse: Left Mouse Button (Drag): Rotate around the universe
controls.rightMouse: Right Mouse Button (Drag): Pan the camera view
controls.scroll: Scroll Wheel: Zoom in and out smoothly

userGuide.freeMoveDescription: When inside an exoplanet universe, you can switch to Free Move Mode for a more immersive experience. After clicking the Enter Free Move button, click the 3D model to lock pointer and begin moving.
userGuide.enableInstructions: Click the 'Enter Free Move' button in the top-left corner. To exit, click 'Exit Free Move'.
userGuide.movementKeysList: W / ↑ Arrow: Move Forward · S / ↓ Arrow: Move Backward · A / ← Arrow: Move Left · D / → Arrow: Move Right
userGuide.exploringExoplanetsParagraph: Each exoplanet model is labeled with its name. You can zoom in closely to inspect the surface. In Free Move Mode, fly between planets and explore them from any angle. Additional info panels (like planet type, distance from Earth, etc.) can be displayed alongside models.
userGuide.mouseMovementParagraph: Look around in any direction while moving. This mode lets you walk or fly through space and get up close to different exoplanets.

tips.title: ⚡ Tips
tips.startInOrbit: Start in Orbit Mode to get a full overview.
tips.useFreeMove: Use Free Move Mode to dive deeper into individual planets.
tips.viewFullscreen: For best experience, view in fullscreen and on a desktop.

hero.description: Leveraging machine learning to discover new worlds in NASA's vast datasets. Our advanced machine learning models identifies exoplanet candidates with unprecedented accuracy, pushing the boundaries of astronomical discovery. Not to mention, we made sure the model is robust against adversarial attacks while preserving its accuracy.

datasets.title: NASA Datasets
datasets.description: Trained on authentic Kepler and TESS mission data, ensuring real-world applicability and scientific validity.

deepLearning.title: Deep Learning
deepLearning.description: Advanced neural architecture designed specifically for light curve analysis and transit detection.

accuracy.title: High Accuracy
accuracy.description: Achieved 95.2% precision with minimal false positives, validated against confirmed exoplanet catalogs.

challenge.title: The Challenge
challenge.description: With thousands of light curves in NASA's archives, manual analysis is impractical. Our AI solution automates the detection of planetary transits, enabling astronomers to focus on confirmation and characterization of the most promising candidates.

demo.title: Model Demo
demo.subtitle: Explore two modes: Guided Discovery for newcomers and Advanced Sandbox for researchers

threshold.title: Confidence Threshold
threshold.description: Move the slider to see how stricter criteria change which objects are considered planets.
threshold.label: Probability Threshold

lightCurve.title: Light Curve Walkthrough
lightCurve.description: This example shows a dip in brightness when the exoplanet passes in front of its star. Our model looks for repeated, evenly spaced dips like this.

explanation.title: What the model is doing
explanation.description: The model compares many features of the light curve (depth, duration, periodicity) to past examples. Changing the threshold only changes what we call a "planet" vs "candidate"—not the underlying score.

dataset.title: Dataset
dataset.description: Upload CSV with two columns: time, flux. Header optional.

results.title: Results & Metrics
results.noResults: Run a job to generate metrics and classifications.
